# Isaiah 61 General Notes
## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

The first part of this chapter is probably a prophecy about the coming Messiah and not Isaiah because this was different than the message Isaiah delivered. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/christ]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Restoration
This chapter prophesies concerning a future time of peace and restoration. It is unlikely to have been fulfilled in Isaiah’s day. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/restore]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/fulfill]])

GLQuote: The Spirit of the Lord Yahweh is on me
OccurrenceNote: “Spirit” here is the Holy Spirit of Yahweh who compels or motivates the person. See how you translated this in [Isaiah 11:2](../11/02.md) or in [Isaiah 42:1](../42/01.md).
This refers to poor people, those in great sorrow, or oppressed people who have problems they cannot overcome by themselves.

GLQuote: liberty to the captives, and the opening of the prison for those who are bound
OccurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. They state that God will certainly give freedom to captives. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Isaiah continues speaking.

GLQuote: the year of Yahweh’s favor, the day of vengeance
OccurrenceNote: Both of these phrases refer to the same span of time. “Year” and “day” are both specific examples that represent the greater whole. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
“time when Yahweh will act kindly toward his people”
Isaiah continues speaking.
Isaiah repeats this for emphasis.
“a headdress” or “a beautiful head covering.” This is a long piece of cloth that is wrapped around the head.

GLQuote: oil of joy…a mantle of praise
OccurrenceNote: People put oil on themselves and dressed in beautiful, long robes during times of celebration and joy. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

GLQuote: in place of a spirit of dullness
OccurrenceNote: “in place of sadness” or “in place of mourning”

GLQuote: oaks of righteousness, the planting of Yahweh
OccurrenceNote: This means Yahweh has caused the people to be strong and sturdy. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “so that the people’s lives may glorify him” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Isaiah continues speaking using parallelisms in each line. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Yahweh’s servant continues speaking to the people of Israel with each line a parallelism. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “People will call you” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
This probably refers to a double portion of land.

GLQuote: they will rejoice over their share…they will…their land…will be theirs
OccurrenceNote: This still refers to the people of Israel. This can be stated in second person. Alternate translation: “you will rejoice over your share…you will…your land…will be yours” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

GLQuote: Their descendants will be known among the nations, and their offspring among the peoples
OccurrenceNote: These two clauses mean the same thing. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “People from other nations will know their descendants” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
This clause assumes the same verb as the previous one. Alternate translation: “their offspring will be known among the peoples” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

GLQuote: I will greatly rejoice in Yahweh
OccurrenceNote: “I” refers to the people of God speaking as one person whom Yahweh has restored.

GLQuote: clothed me with the garments of salvation; he has clothed me with the robe of righteousness
OccurrenceNote: The people of God speaking as one person now have salvation and righteousness as their distinct appearance visible to all. “Garments” and “robe” are clothing that everyone can see. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: as a bridegroom adorns himself with a turban, and as a bride adorns herself with her jewels
OccurrenceNote: This comparison emphasizes that the speaker is extremely happy, joyful, celebrating. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
See how you translated this in [Isaiah 61:3](../61/03.md).

GLQuote: For as the earth produces its sprouting plants, and as the garden makes its planting grow
OccurrenceNote: This is saying the same thing in two ways. The fact that whatever God says he will do is certainly going to happen is compared to the fact that seeds sprout after planting. Alternate translation: “Just as seeds sown in a garden sprout from the soil and grow” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

GLQuote: righteousness and praise to sprout up
OccurrenceNote: This expression describes these virtues as growing from seed like plants do. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Isaiah 62 General Notes
## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Restoration
This chapter prophesies concerning a future time of peace and restoration. It is unlikely to have been fulfilled in Isaiah’s day. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/restore]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/fulfill]])

GLQuote: For Zion’s sake I will not be silent, and for Jerusalem’s sake I will not be quiet
OccurrenceNote: Both of these statements mean the same thing. Here “Zion” and “Jerusalem” both represent the people who live in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “For the sake of the people of Jerusalem I will not be silent” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
It is most likely that “I” refers to Isaiah.

GLQuote: until her righteousness proceeds brightly, and her salvation as a burning torch
OccurrenceNote: Both clauses reassure the people that God will eventually come and save the people of Israel and that it will be as apparent as light is. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

GLQuote: You will also be a crown of beauty in the hand of Yahweh, and a turban of kingship in the hand of your God
OccurrenceNote: These mean the same thing and are combined for emphasis. They say that Jerusalem will become a royal city under the power and authority of God. Yahweh’s hand is a metonym for his power and authority. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

GLQuote: It will no more…will it be said, “Desolate.”
OccurrenceNote: These mean the same thing are combined for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

GLQuote: It will no more be said of you
OccurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “People will no longer say about you” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

GLQuote: nor of your land any longer will it be said
OccurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “nor will people any longer say about your land” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
This means Yahweh will love the people of Israel and will always be with them as is a husband. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: as a young man marries a young woman, so your sons will marry you
OccurrenceNote: Here “sons” refers to the people of Israel and “you” refers to Judah, the land of Israel. This means the people will take possession of the land as a man takes possession of his young wife. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

GLQuote: as a bridegroom rejoices over his bride, your God will rejoice over you
OccurrenceNote: This emphasizes God’s happiness about his relationship with his people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
Here “I” may refer to Isaiah or to Yahweh.

This refers to prophets, officials, or possibly angels, who are constantly praying for the people of Jerusalem like watchmen who constantly guard the city. See how you translated “watchmen” in [Isaiah 52:8](../52/08.md) and [Isaiah 56:10](../56/10.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: they are not silent day or night
OccurrenceNote: This means they are continually pleading to Yahweh or calling to each other. Alternate translation: “they are earnestly praying to Yahweh throughout the entire day” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

GLQuote: Do not allow him to rest
OccurrenceNote: Here “him” refers to Yahweh.

GLQuote: by his right hand and by the arm of his strength
OccurrenceNote: The right hand and arm represent power and authority. Alternate translation: “by his power and authority” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

GLQuote: Surely I will no longer give your grain as food for your enemies
OccurrenceNote: This means Yahweh will not let enemies conquer the people of Israel and take their grain anymore. Perhaps enemies took the grain in the past as a tax or to feed their own armies.

GLQuote: I will no longer give your grain as food for your enemies…Foreigners will not drink your new wine
OccurrenceNote: These statements are set together for emphasis and completion. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

GLQuote: those who harvest the grain…those who pick the grapes
OccurrenceNote: These statements are set together for emphasis and completion. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

GLQuote: Come through, come through the gates
OccurrenceNote: The phrase “come through” is repeated to show urgency.

The word “build” is repeated to emphasize that Yahweh urgently wants the road prepared. The “highway” represents the way the people can return. This is similar to [Isaiah 40:3](../40/03.md) and [Isaiah 57:14](../57/14.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
“Take the stones out of the road to make it smooth.” Stones represent all the obstacles to quick travel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

GLQuote: Raise up a signal flag for the nations
OccurrenceNote: A signal flag represents something to draw the attention of others. This means Yahweh is calling the people of the other nations to take notice of the land of Israel and to see what Yahweh has accomplished as he said he would. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
“Take notice!”

The places on the earth that are very far away are spoken of as if they were the places where the earth ends. This phrase also forms a merism and refers to everywhere in between the ends. See how you translated this in [Isaiah 40:28](../40/28.md). AT “the farthest places of the earth” or “the entire earth” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
“Daughter” represents the people of Jerusalem (Zion). See how you translated this in [Isaiah 1:8](../01/08.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

GLQuote: See, his reward is with him, and his recompense is going before him
OccurrenceNote: These clauses represent the same idea for emphasis. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Isaiah 40:10](../40/10.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
This can be stated actively, “they will call you” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

# Isaiah 63 General Notes
## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### Imagery
The imagery of judgment in this chapter is intended to be rather vivid. The translator should avoid euphemisms, if possible. Overall, this chapter prophesies a day of great judgment and God’s wrath. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/judge]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/wrath]])

GLQuote: Who is this who comes from Edom…Bozrah
OccurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks as a watchman using the question and answer format to present this information about Yahweh’s judgment on Edom, an enemy of Israel. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: “I, Yahweh, am coming from Edom, clothed in red from Bozrah” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
This is the capital city of Edom. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
Here “I” refers to Yahweh.

GLQuote: Why are your clothes red, and why…winepress?
OccurrenceNote: This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: “The red on your clothing looks makes you look like you have been treading on grapes in a winepress.” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
A winepress is a low place carved out of rock in the ground where workers step on the grapes to crush them with their feet, in order to remove the grape juice.
Here “I” refers to Yahweh. This imagery refers to Yahweh destroying his enemies. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
“the time of vengeance” or “the time for vengeance”
Yahweh will punish in an appropriate way to bring about justice. His kind of vengeance differs from man’s vengeance.
Here “year” refers to a specific time appointed by Yahweh for restoring Israel. Alternate translation: “the time for my redemption” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Yahweh continues speaking.
Here “arm” represents power. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

GLQuote: made them drunk in my wrath
OccurrenceNote: This means Yahweh made them stunned and senseless by his full wrath and punishment. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here “blood” represents the life of Yahweh’s enemies that was gushing out so they would die. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: I will tell of the acts of Yahweh’s covenant faithfulness
OccurrenceNote: The abstract noun “faithfulness” can be stated as “faithfully” or “faithful.” See how you translated “covenant faithfulness” in [Isaiah 16:5](../16/05.md). Alternate translation: “I will tell about how God has acted faithfully to his covenant” or “I will tell about all the faithful things God has done for his people” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
Here “I” refers to Isaiah.
Here “us” refers to Isaiah and the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-inclusive]])
“Through all our suffering.” Here “their” refers to the people of Israel. Isaiah included himself as a member of the people.
Here “he” refers to Yahweh.
This is a representative who is sent from God’s presence.

GLQuote: he lifted them up and carried them
OccurrenceNote: This refers to when God protected and saved the people of Israel from the Egyptians many years earlier. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
“but we rebelled.” Here “they” refers to the people of Israel. Isaiah included himself as a member of the people.
“Yahweh’s Holy Spirit”
“we said.” Here “they” refers to the people of Israel. Isaiah included himself as a member of the people.

GLQuote: who brought them up out of the sea
OccurrenceNote: The story of Yahweh miraculously splitting the waters of the Sea of Reeds so that the Israelites could cross and escape the Egyptians is assumed knowledge. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Leaders are sometimes referred to as “shepherds.” Alternate translation: “the leaders of his people” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The people of Israel continue speaking.

GLQuote: who made his glorious power go with the right hand of Moses
OccurrenceNote: Here “right hand” represents the power of Yahweh through Moses. This means it was God’s power that enabled Moses to divide the water of the Reed Sea. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

GLQuote: Like a horse running on flat land, they did not stumble
OccurrenceNote: This means that the people of Israel were sure-footed as horses in open country on their travels toward Israel from Egypt. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
The people of Israel continue speaking.

GLQuote: As the cattle that go down into the valley…rest
OccurrenceNote: This image pictures cattle going into a valley where there is green grass and water and emphasizes that God led the people of Israel and took care of them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

GLQuote: to make yourself a name of praise
OccurrenceNote: Here “name of praise” refers to honor and one’s reputation. Alternate translation: “to make sure you have an honored reputation for yourself” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
The people of Israel continue speaking.

GLQuote: Where are your zeal and your mighty acts?
OccurrenceNote: The writer uses a question to express deep emotion and concern because it seems God is not helping them. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: “We do not see your zeal and your mighty acts!” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

GLQuote: Your pity and your compassionate actions are kept from us
OccurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “You keep your pity and compassion from us” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

GLQuote: though Abraham does not know us, and Israel does not recognize us
OccurrenceNote: These ancestors of the nation of Israel would not able to identify their descendants because they changed so much. “Abraham” and “Israel” represent the people from the distant past. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
This refers to the name also called “Jacob.”
The people of Israel continue speaking.

GLQuote: Yahweh, why do you make us wander from your ways and harden our hearts, so we do not obey you?
OccurrenceNote: Here the writer uses a question to express a complaint of the people to God. This question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: “Yahweh, you have made us wander from your ways and become stubborn so that we do not obey you.” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

GLQuote: why do you make us wander from your ways
OccurrenceNote: To not do what Yahweh commands is spoken of as if a person wanders off of the correct path. Alternate translation: “why do you make do what is wrong” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This means to become resistant to Yahweh’s teaching by refusing to listen and obey. Here “heart” represents their motives, feelings and desires. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The people of Israel continue speaking.

GLQuote: who were never called by your name
OccurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. The word “name” refers to a family relationship. Alternate translation: “who never belonged to your family” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

GLQuote: We have become…called by your name
OccurrenceNote: Some modern versions interpret this passage differently: “We are like the people over whom you have not ruled, like those who have not been called by your name.”

# Isaiah 64 General Notes
## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Repentance
This chapter records the repentance of the righteous remnant of Judah. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/repent]], [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/righteous]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/remnant]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]])
The people of Israel continue speaking to Yahweh ([Isaiah 63:11](../63/11.md)).
Isaiah introduces this desire for Yahweh’s presence in their past history with a strong exclamation. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])

GLQuote: if you had split open the heavens
OccurrenceNote: If Yahweh had shown himself very dramatically by tearing open the sky. The words “split open” refer to ripping a piece of cloth apart. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The mountains would have trembled as in an earthquake. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])

GLQuote: as when fire kindles the brushwood, or the fire makes water boil
OccurrenceNote: This possibly emphasizes how easily God’s presence would have caused the mountains and the people to tremble. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
The people of Israel continues speaking to Yahweh.
Here the “eye” refers to the whole person. Alternate translation: “nor has anyone seen” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
The people of Israel continue speaking to Yahweh.
This is an idiom that means “remember.” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
The people of Israel continue speaking to Yahweh.

GLQuote: all our righteous deeds are like a menstrual rag
OccurrenceNote: A “menstrual rag” is a cloth that a woman uses during the time of month when she bleeds from her womb. This means all their attempts to please God fail. This sentence was meant to be shocking. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

GLQuote: We have all withered like leaves
OccurrenceNote: Isaiah compares the people of Israel to leaves that dry up when dead. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

GLQuote: our iniquities, like the wind, carry us away
OccurrenceNote: This means their sins, as a community, are the reason for their failure. Isaiah compares the iniquities to the wind as the force for their suffering Yahweh’s punishment. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

GLQuote: you have hidden your face from us
OccurrenceNote: This means God gave up on his people and let them suffer. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

GLQuote: in the hand of our iniquities
OccurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” is a metonym for the power of those who are punishing the people for their iniquities. Alternate translation: “as you punish us for our iniquities” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
The people of Israel continue speaking to Yahweh.

GLQuote: we are the clay. You are our potter; and we all are the work of your hand
OccurrenceNote: This means God created the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This refers to remembering the past. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Isaiah asks Yahweh to pay attention to their situation. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
The people of Israel continue speaking to Yahweh.

GLQuote: Your holy cities have become a wilderness
OccurrenceNote: This emphasizes that the cities have been destroyed and no one lives there.

GLQuote: Our holy and beautiful temple, where our fathers praised you, has been destroyed by fire
OccurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “The enemy has destroyed our holy and beautiful temple, where our fathers praised you, by fire” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

GLQuote: How can you still hold back, Yahweh? How can you remain silent and continue to humiliate us?
OccurrenceNote: They use questions to express their frustration because God has not yet come to help them. Alternate translation: “Please do not hold back, Yahweh! Please do not remain silent and continue to humiliate us!” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

# Isaiah 65 General Notes
## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

This chapter is Yahweh’s response to the repentance of the people. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/repent]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Judgment and hope
This chapter records that Yahweh’s judgment on the people must come. Despite this, there is hope that in the end, Yahweh will make all things new and restore them to himself. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/judge]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/hope]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/restore]])
Here “I” refers to Yahweh.

GLQuote: I have spread out my hands all day to a stubborn people
OccurrenceNote: “Spreading out my hands” here is a person’s gesture to show imploring or a strong request. Alternate translation: “I have continually begged a stubborn people to receive my help” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Yahweh continues speaking about the people of Israel.

These refer to Canaanite places for worshiping idols. Their sacred altars were made of bricks, which Yahweh forbid for his altars. Yahweh’s altars were made of stone. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

GLQuote: sit among the graves and keep watch all night
OccurrenceNote: This is a reference to consulting the dead, a practice that Yahweh prohibited. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Yahweh did not allow the people of Israel to eat meat from pigs. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Yahweh continues speaking to and about the people of Israel.

GLQuote: These things are smoke in my nose
OccurrenceNote: Yahweh compares these people who are continually annoying him to smoke that irritates a person’s breathing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: a fire that burns all day long
OccurrenceNote: Yahweh compares the people of Israel to a slow-burning fire that sends out smoke without stopping as it irritates. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Yahweh continues speaking about the people of Israel.
“Take notice and pay attention”

This means God will punish them to the fullest extent. This expression compares Yahweh punishing the people to dumping on their legs as they are sitting. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: As when juice is found in a cluster of grapes
OccurrenceNote: Yahweh compares the people of Israel to a cluster of grapes that still has some good juice in it. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: when juice is found in a cluster
OccurrenceNote: This can be stated in an active way. Alternate translation: “when you find juice in a cluster” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

GLQuote: I will not ruin them all
OccurrenceNote: This can be expressed positively. Alternate translation: “I will spare some of them who are righteous” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Yahweh continues speaking.
This refers to the highest locations of Jerusalem and all of Judea.
This was a fertile grazing area. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
This is the name of a valley that possibly ran from Jerusalem to south of Jericho. This was also a fertile grazing area. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
Yahweh continues speaking.
See how you translated this in [Isaiah 11:9](../11/09.md).

GLQuote: who prepare a table…and fill wine glasses of mixed wine
OccurrenceNote: People would bring food and drink and place it in front of the idol as part of their worship.
wine mixed with spices
These are names of false gods. They are also called “Gad” and “Meni.”
Yahweh continues speaking to those in Israel who worship idols.
“The sword” represents various weapons of war that Yahweh will use to punish those who do not respond to Yahweh’s call. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

GLQuote: when I called, you did not answer; when I spoke, you did not listen
OccurrenceNote: Both clauses mean the same and are repeated for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Yahweh continues speaking to those in Israel who worship idols.
“Take notice and pay attention” Yahweh repeats this for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

GLQuote: but you will cry because of the pain of the heart, and will wail because of the crushing of the spirit
OccurrenceNote: These clauses mean the same and the repetition is for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
This expression compares the feeling of terrible disappointment and sorrow to something becoming deformed due to high pressure. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Yahweh continues speaking to those in Israel who worship idols.

GLQuote: will be blessed by me, the God of truth
OccurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “I, the God who always speaks the truth, will bless him” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

GLQuote: the former troubles will be forgotten…will be hidden
OccurrenceNote: These clauses can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “they will forget the former troubles, for these troubles will be out of my memory” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

GLQuote: they will be hidden from my eyes
OccurrenceNote: “hidden from my eyes” represents the attention and memory of Yahweh. Alternate translation: “I will not even think about them again” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
Yahweh continues speaking.
“Notice! Pay attention!”

GLQuote: new heavens and a new earth
OccurrenceNote: Both are extremes that also represent everything between. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

GLQuote: the former things will not be remembered or be brought to mind
OccurrenceNote: Both of these clauses mean the same thing and are combined for emphasis. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “you will not even think about what happened in the past” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Here “you” refers to all of God’s servants. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])

GLQuote: weeping and cries of distress will no longer be heard in her
OccurrenceNote: You can state this in active form. Alternate translation: “no one will hear weeping and cries of distress any longer in her” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Yahweh continues speaking about his faithful people.
“100 years” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])

GLQuote: will be considered a young person
OccurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “people will consider him a young person” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
This can be stated this in active form. Alternate translation: “people will consider this person as cursed” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Yahweh continues speaking about his faithful people.

GLQuote: for as the days of trees will be the days of my people
OccurrenceNote: “for my people will live as long as trees live”

GLQuote: they are the children of those blessed by Yahweh
OccurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “they are the children of those whom Yahweh blessed” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Yahweh continues speaking about his faithful people.
See how you translated this in [Isaiah 11:9](../11/09.md).

# Isaiah 66 General Notes
## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in 66:1-17, 21-24.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### In the end
In the end, Yahweh will enact his perfect justice. This is the true hope of this world. The new heaven and the new earth are an important part of this. In the end, this will be the perfect creation of Yahweh and will last forever. (See: [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/justice]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/hope]] and [[rc://en/tw/dict/bible/kt/eternity]])

GLQuote: Heaven is my throne, and the earth is my footstool
OccurrenceNote: Yahweh compares heaven to a throne and the earth to a footstool to emphasize how great he is. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: Where then is the house you will build for me? Where is the place where I may rest?
OccurrenceNote: Yahweh uses questions to emphasize that humans cannot build a place for him to dwell. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
Yahweh continues speaking.

GLQuote: My hand has made all these things
OccurrenceNote: Yahweh is represented by his hand which emphasizes his power and authority. Alternate translation: “I have made all these things” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Yahweh speaks of himself by name to express the certainty of what he is declaring. Translate as in [Isaiah 30:1](../30/01.md). Alternate translation: “this is what Yahweh has declared” or “this is what I, Yahweh, have declared” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

GLQuote: the broken and contrite in spirit
OccurrenceNote: Here “broken” and “contrite” refers to a person who is truly humble and who suffers for his faith.
Yahweh continues speaking.
These four clauses all describe different ways evil people act and come to the same meaning for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

GLQuote: They have chosen their own ways
OccurrenceNote: “They have chosen to do evil things that violate the ways of Yahweh”
Yahweh continues speaking about the wicked people.

GLQuote: what was evil in my sight
OccurrenceNote: Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: “what I consider to be evil” or “what is evil in my judgement” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “Glorify Yahweh” or “May Yahweh glorify himself” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

GLQuote: but they will be put to shame
OccurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “but I will put them to shame” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Yahweh describes the punishment for the hypocrisy of the worshipers.
The sound represents the real fighting that is going on in the temple as Yahweh is carrying out the punishment. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Yahweh continues speaking.

GLQuote: Before she goes into labor, she gives birth; before pain is upon her, she gave birth to a son
OccurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks about Zion as if it were a woman who is about to give birth. Although Zion was destroyed and the people no longer lived there, Yahweh promises that without delay and with little effort an entire nation will come from her. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: Who has heard of such a thing? Who has seen such things? Will a land be born in one day? Can a nation be established in one moment?
OccurrenceNote: Yahweh uses questions to emphasize how unique this event will be. The series of questions builds tension until Zion is finally mentioned. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
Yahweh continues speaking about Jerusalem as if it were a mother ([Isaiah 66:7-8](./07.md)).

GLQuote: Do I bring a baby to the birth opening…born?
OccurrenceNote: Yahweh uses questions to emphasize that he will not fail to fulfill his promises to the people of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Yahweh continues speaking about Jerusalem as if it were a mother and the inhabitants of Jerusalem as if they were newly born children ([Isaiah 66:7-8](./07.md)).

GLQuote: For you will nurse and be satisfied; with her breasts you will be comforted
OccurrenceNote: This means Jerusalem will be a place of safety and comfort for God’s people. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “For she will satisfy you with her milk; she will comfort you with her breasts” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Yahweh continues speaking about Jerusalem as if it were a mother ([Isaiah 66:7-8](./07.md)).

GLQuote: like a river…like an overflowing stream
OccurrenceNote: This means God will cause the people of the nations to bring a very large amount of riches, which will be permanent like a river and abundant. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

GLQuote: You will nurse at her side, be carried in her arms, and be dandled on her knees
OccurrenceNote: This means Jerusalem will be a place of safety and comfort for God’s people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

GLQuote: be carried in her arms, and be dandled on her knees
OccurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “she will carry you in her arms and bounce you on her knees with delight” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

GLQuote: so I will comfort you, and you will be comforted in Jerusalem
OccurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “so I will comfort you in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Isaiah is speaking to God’s faithful people.
“Bones” refers to the whole body. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

GLQuote: will sprout like the tender grass
OccurrenceNote: “Tender grass” grows fast and strong and compares to the health and vigor of God’s faithful people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

GLQuote: The hand of Yahweh will be made known to his servants
OccurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to his power. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will reveal his power to his servants” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Isaiah continues speaking to God’s faithful people.
Yahweh’s appearances in the Old Testament are often accompanied by fire that represents Yahweh’s anger and judgment. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Storms represent Yahweh’s powerful actions to make his judgment effective. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
“Sword” is one weapon that represents all of warfare and killing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

GLQuote: Those killed by Yahweh will be many
OccurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will kill many people” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Isaiah continues speaking.
“They” are those who worship Yahweh but go against his laws.
This is a place where people would go to worship idols. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
This describes the leader of those of go to worship idols.

Yahweh speaks of himself by name to express the certainty of what he is declaring. Translate as in [Isaiah 30:1](../30/01.md). Alternate translation: “this is what Yahweh has declared” or “this is what I, Yahweh, have declared” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
Here “I” refers to Yahweh.
Here “their” refers to the worshipers that are hypocrites whom Yahweh has described before.
These are names of areas that are far from the land of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
Here “they” refers to the foreigners who survived and witnessed to the nations. They will return to Jerusalem with exiled Israelites.
See how you translated this in [Isaiah 11:9](../11/09.md).

GLQuote: the new heavens and the new earth
OccurrenceNote: See how you translated this in [Isaiah 65:17](../65/17.md).
Yahweh finishes speaking.
Here “they” refers to all the people, the faithful Israelites and foreigners, who come to worship Yahweh.
Both clauses describe the same idea to emphasize Yahweh’s punishment. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
The worms represent the horror of decay and rot that are Yahweh’s punishment on the wicked. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Fire also represents Yahweh’s judgment. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
This can be expressed positively. Alternate translation: “will burn forever” (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
This expression represents all created living beings that shrink from the dead. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
